Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada due to Serious Criminality

Decision_Outcome: IAD’s decision set aside, matter referred to a different panel for redetermination

Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness, lack of opportunity to make full submissions on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of IAD decision, redetermination by a new panel
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside, redetermination ordered

Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness

National_Security_Element: Alleged involvement in drug smuggling at airport

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purpose of trafficking

Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Allegations based on undisclosed RCMP reports

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee status criteria
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA and Regulations - Refugee and Humanitarian Protection Criteria
Application_Facts: Mayelli Kamara fled Sierra Leone due to civil war; claimed need for refugee status or humanitarian protection; children included in application
Claimant_Status: Applicant for refugee status under Convention refugees abroad class or country of asylum class
Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in visa officer's assessment
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on post-conflict Sierra Leone
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating targeted persecution
Insufficient proof of ongoing risk upon return
Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found applicant did not credibly demonstrate individualized risk or persecution
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's refusal
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of refusal decision and grant of protected person status
Legal_Standard_Applied: Definition of Convention refugee and country of asylum class
Decision_Rationale: No evidence of targeted persecution; post-conflict conditions in Sierra Leone allow for safe repatriation; no durable solution issues established
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose previous refusals or removals

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to disclose a prior U.S. refugee claim and removal despite clear form instructions
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to disclose prior removal
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Withholding material facts that could induce error in visa assessment

Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa application form, instructions, record of U.S. removal
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to disclose material immigration history
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative due to omission of key facts
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Omission was material and affected assessment of intent to leave Canada

Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to disclose relevant immigration history

Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in officer’s misrepresentation finding
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Record of U.S. removal and refugee claim
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Visa officer maintained refusal based on non-disclosure

Legal_Issue: Is the trademark 'The Mild One' registrable under the Trade-marks Act despite being potentially descriptive?
Procedural_Stage: Appeal under Section 56(1) of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: New evidence showed similar trademarks were registered; structure and disclaimer of 'MILD' contribute to distinctiveness
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court overturned the Registrar's decision
Credibility_Factor: Registrar initially rejected application; additional evidence presented on appeal
Legal_Rule: Section 12(1)(b): prohibits clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive marks; Section 35: allows disclaimers; Section 56(1): provides right of appeal
Standard_of_Review: Statutory appeal standard under the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Trademark is distinctive as a whole despite descriptive component
Key_Evidence_Considered: Similar trademarks previously registered, disclaimer of 'MILD', overall distinctiveness
Legal_Framework: Canadian federal trademark law, Trade-marks Act
Defendant_Response: Registrar opposed registration on grounds of descriptiveness
Remedy_Requested: Registration of the trademark 'The Mild One'
Legal_Provision: Section 12(1)(b), Section 35, Section 56(1) of the Trade-marks Act

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in finding the applicant inadmissible due to membership in a terrorist organization

Crimes.Application_Factor: Need for corroborating documentation and risk of harm
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged irregularities in Tazkira (signatures, stamps, procurement)

Crimes.Victim_Status: Survivor of domestic abuse seeking refugee protection
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Threats linked to control and retaliation for perceived disloyalty
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Not assessed due to lack of formal reporting
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threat of lethal violence
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm if returned to Afghanistan
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Personalized and ongoing threat from spouse
Crimes.Threat_Source: Husband threatening death if applicant 'conspired' against him
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on marital relationship and gender

Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: RPD doubted credibility; court found dismissal unreasonable
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD failed to properly analyze gravity of threats

Crimes.Victim_Status: Survivor of domestic and sexual violence

Crimes.Targeted_Individual: Female survivor of spousal sexual abuse

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Physical, emotional, and psychological abuse by spouse

Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: RPD did not adequately assess credibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Findings deemed unreasonable by Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving indirect involvement in drug trafficking
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA sections on criminality and inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to allow time to rebut allegations or provide evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Applicant sought time to obtain corroborative evidence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision set aside, remitted to new panel
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged involvement via spouse’s drug trafficking activities
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Claimant entered Canada as asylum seeker
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No direct involvement alleged; association through husband
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential implication under organized crime provisions
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Fear of persecution due to association with criminal activity (forced participation or retaliation)
Crimes.Outcome: Remittal for reconsideration due to procedural unfairness
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Unreasonable assessment of identity and credibility, denial of fair process
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, particularly provisions on refugee protection and criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Refusal to grant adjournment despite legitimate need for evidence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether detention review decisions contained reviewable errors regarding release conditions and flight risk assessment
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Subsection 58(1); Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRP Regulations), Section 248
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Identity concerns initially present, but mitigated by new surety and family presence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Length of detention, unexplained delays, alternatives to detention, bond amount, surety, family ties
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Detention based on identity deception and people smuggling involvement
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Recent changes reducing flight risk: family presence, increased bond, new surety
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of immigration detention review decisions
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged error in assessing flight risk and release conditions
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Release unless danger to public or unlikely to appear for removal
Crimes.Application_Factor: Flight risk, identity concerns, security risks, inadmissibility for organized criminality
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division, Immigration and Refugee Board
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border documents upon arrival

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to leave Canada after temporary status expired
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s.24(1) - failure to comply with conditions or departure order
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Subsection 58(1); IRP Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondent detained for 19 months due to unresolved PRRA and inadmissibility issues
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national subject to immigration detention
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to prolonged stay beyond authorized period
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Delays in processing PRRA and lack of clear timeline for removal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family ties in Canada, surety, ongoing legal processes, length of detention
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Cooperative with authorities, stable community connections
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Detention justified only if danger to public or unlikely to appear
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Prolonged detention without foreseeable end not justified given mitigating factors

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention review based on inadmissibility for organized criminality

Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Involvement in people smuggling via MV Sun Sea
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Arrival by irregular maritime vessel (MV Sun Sea)
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Deemed inadmissible for organized criminality related to smuggling
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Security risk and moderate flight risk
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Balancing flight risk against evolving personal circumstances and lengthy detention
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s.58(1), s.37; IRP Regulations s.248

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's decision based on credibility and state protection availability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding due to contradictions and omissions in testimony and forms
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, written statements, Personal Information Forms (PIFs)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections related to misrepresentation and refugee eligibility under IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to threats in home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility and failure to test state protection in Mexico
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission of key information in application forms and inconsistencies in statements
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; Board considered all relevant evidence consistent with its mandate
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard for negative credibility findings and burden to demonstrate lack of state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in accounts of persecution and failure to seek local protection
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No forgery, but material omissions and misrepresentations in official forms

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to an immigration officer
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's decision based on applicant's credibility and state protection availability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to contradictions between entry statements and testimony
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Port of entry statements, hearing testimony, application documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions prohibiting false statements in immigration proceedings

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent identification of persecutors and lack of proof regarding state protection
Crimes.Application_Error: Contradictions at port of entry and omission of critical details
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; court found Board’s analysis sufficient and evidence properly weighed
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard for assessing credibility and rebutting presumption of state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: False or inconsistent statements about identity of persecutors
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False oral/written statements at entry, not document forgery

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose material facts in Personal Information Form
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's decision based on lack of credibility and failure to rebut state protection presumption
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility undermined by contradictions and omissions in PIF and testimony
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal Information Form (PIF), oral testimony, supporting documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Requirements for full disclosure in immigration applications
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Threats from Mexican political party members
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Material omissions in PIF and failure to access state protection in Mexico
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose knowledge of fraud and inconsistencies in political timeline
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No indication of ignored evidence; Board relied on available credible information
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to disclose material facts and burden to prove ineffective state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: Non-disclosure of key facts in mandatory forms
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed, no relief granted on judicial review
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Material omissions in official immigration form (PIF)

Legal_Issue: Whether the defendants infringed the plaintiffs' patent for a fabric with oppositely facing furry surfaces
Evidence_Assessment: Defendants' garments have fur on oppositely facing surfaces; natural twisting occurs in production process; reinforcement method does not avoid infringement
Decision_Outcome: Defendants found liable for patent infringement
Credibility_Factor: Court accepted that natural twisting results in a product within the scope of the patent claims
Legal_Rule: Infringement occurs when an act interferes with the monopoly granted by a patent; the court must determine if the defendant's product falls within the scope of the patent claims
Standard_of_Review: Claim construction and factual comparison of products
Grounds_for_Claim: Manufacture and sale of garments using a method resulting in a product covered by the plaintiffs' patent claims 1 to 4
Key_Evidence_Considered: Structure and composition of the defendants' fabric; manufacturing process; similarity to patented product
Legal_Framework: Patent claims analysis, scope of protection, doctrine of equivalents (implied)
Defendant_Response: Denial of deliberate twisting; argument that reinforcement differentiates their product
Evidence_Type: Product samples, technical descriptions, process documentation
Remedy_Requested: Permanent injunction, damages, and/or accounting of profits
Outcome: Permanent injunction granted; further proceedings for damages or profits ordered

Legal_Issue: Whether the Veterans Review and Appeal Board erred in concluding that Wood's low back pain was not service-related
Governing_Law: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act
Evidence_Assessment: Board ignored uncontradicted evidence, including medical records and Major Zaporzan's letter; dismissed relevant medical reports without explanation
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show service connection, but uncontradicted evidence must be considered favorably
Credibility_Factor: Uncontradicted medical evidence and military officer's statement
Legal_Rule: Board must consider uncontradicted evidence favorably and resolve doubts in applicant’s favor
Grounds_for_Claim: Low back pain originated from military service
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim initially denied due to insufficient evidence; court found error in evaluation
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical records, Major Zaporzan's letter, military service activities
Defendant_Response: Board rejected claim citing insufficient evidence
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (medical records), sworn statements, official correspondence
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Board decision, quashing of decision, re-determination
Outcome: Application allowed, decision quashed, remanded for reconsideration by different panel
Legal_Provision: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the officer improperly fetter his discretion by not considering post-leave-decision evidence of establishment?
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's choice to remain illegally in Canada
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to consider post-leave evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Officer must consider all evidence but may assign weight based on circumstances

Crimes.Application_Facts: Entered Canada with a false passport; refugee claim rejected; remained without status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Use of false passport at entry
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether officer properly considered post-leave establishment evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Permanent residence based on H&C grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Officer may weigh evidence; staying illegally by choice does not warrant relief
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Establishment resulted from voluntary illegal stay; no procedural unfairness

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada after removal order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada despite removal order; sought H&C relief
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether officer fettered discretion by not weighing post-leave evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Establishment due to personal choice does not justify H&C relief
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer considered evidence but reasonably assigned no weight due to illegal stay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to comply with a removal order
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the officer improperly fetter discretion by not considering post-leave establishment evidence?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Post-leave establishment evidence considered but discounted
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate H&C grounds
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Staying illegally by choice does not warrant H&C relief

Crimes.Crime_Name: Prescribed senior official in the service of a government engaging in terrorism, systematic or gross human rights violations, genocide, war crimes, or crimes against humanity
National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with genocidal regime
Threat_Assessment: Presumption of complicity based on position
Nature_of_Acts: Genocide, war crimes, crimes against humanity
Admission_or_Involvement: Presumed involvement due to official status
Evidence_Credibility: Credible public record of regime’s actions
Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of individual exculpatory evidence considered
Credibility_Assessment: Not assessed individually due to irrebuttable presumption
Standard_of_Proof: Presumption without need for individual proof
Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 35(1)(b)
Governing_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 16
Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility to Canada, denial of refugee protection

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility for violating human or international rights
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Judicial review challenging constitutionality of inadmissibility
Grounds_for_Claim: Senior official in regime committing genocide
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Institutional_Action: Canada Border Services Agency determination upheld
Government_Body_or_Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Protected_Group: Victims of genocide and crimes against humanity
State_Protection_Assessment: Regime failed to protect its citizens
Risk_Factor: High risk of persecution and harm due to regime actions
Credibility: Claimant's lack of individual defense permitted
State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate protection by Rwandan government during genocide
Risk_Nature: Systematic extermination based on ethnic identity
Perpetrator_Entity: Government of Rwanda and affiliated forces

Legal_Issue: Fairness and procedural correctness of visa officer's decision on education points
Evidence_Assessment: Visa officer failed to fully consider specialized training evidence
Decision_Outcome: 20 points awarded for Education criterion instead of 25 or 22
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate procedural unfairness
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's professional qualifications as an Iranian ophthalmologist
Legal_Rule: Visa officer decisions reviewed for reasonableness; procedural fairness issues subject to correctness review
Standard_of_Review: Correctness (due to alleged procedural fairness violation)
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure to properly assess education credentials and specialized training
Outcome_on_Merits: Visa officer's decision found procedurally unfair
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical degree classification, specialized training documentation
Legal_Framework: Canadian administrative law, IRPA, principles of procedural fairness
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of education and professional training
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, re-evaluation by another visa officer
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded for revaluation

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in its sur place claim by making contradictory findings and selectively analyzing evidence?
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court allowed the application for judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility questioned; inconsistencies noted but not fully explained
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, including Amnesty International report
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Sur place refugee claim based on activities after leaving Sri Lanka
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: LTTE association and risk upon return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Application_Error: Selective analysis of evidence and inconsistent findings
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard requiring justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Amnesty International report on country conditions and risks for LTTE-linked individuals
Crimes.Application_Factor: Risk of detention and persecution upon return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected initially; decision set aside on judicial review
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim involving illegal entry
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to irregular arrival
Crimes.Outcome: Claim rejected by RPD; Federal Court remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to perceived LTTE links
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, Charter of Rights and Freedoms, IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Initial rejection overturned; case remitted to new panel
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refugee status denied despite documented country risks
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Refugee claimant arriving irregularly via MV Sun Sea
Crimes.Protected_Group: Persons with political opinion or membership in particular social group
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Sri Lankan Tamils perceived as linked to LTTE
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Inadequate state protection in Sri Lanka for returned asylum seekers
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Risk of arbitrary detention, torture, or ill-treatment upon return
Crimes.Credibility: Partially accepted but undermined by lack of documentary corroboration
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Found inadequate in general, but not applied consistently to applicant
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Serious harm including detention and interrogation by Sri Lankan authorities
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Imputed political opinion due to presence on MV Sun Sea and alleged LTTE ties

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 16(1) of IRPA – misrepresentation affecting admissibility
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk due to sur place activities but provided inconsistent testimony
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Sri Lankan national arriving irregularly in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Unauthorized entry and stay pending refugee determination
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged false statements regarding extent of LTTE involvement
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly assess documentary evidence supporting claim
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over immigration and refugee matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Country condition reports, personal testimony, AI documentation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient weight given to credible country evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mixed assessment; some elements accepted, others dismissed without rationale
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed; later found unreasonable on judicial review
Crimes.Outcome: Remitted for redetermination by a different panel
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and remittal of decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence of credible LTTE ties and personal risk

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving organized human smuggling operation
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA sections on inadmissibility due to organized criminal activity
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to address key evidence impacting risk assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Public record through judicial review proceedings
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected; decision found unreasonable and remitted
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Arrival in Canada via MV Sun Sea, part of large-scale smuggling operation
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Irregular maritime arrival with 499 other passengers
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No individual criminal charges, but association with smuggling event
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential implication in organized criminal activity under IRPA s. 37
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Risk upon return linked to both state and non-state actors in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Amnesty International, UNHCR, and IRB country reports
Crimes.Outcome: Initial refusal; quashed and remitted by Federal Court
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Lack of credible evidence linking applicant directly to smuggling network
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to justify dismissal of key documentary evidence

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed her visa, had an unsuccessful humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application, and requested deferral of removal due to her daughter’s medical needs. Medical care availability in St. Vincent was confirmed by the officer.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for deferral of removal based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Medical reports, H&C application records, confirmation of healthcare access in St. Vincent
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No credibility issues raised
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of removal officer's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under s. 25(1) IRPA; limited discretion under s. 48 IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer acted within mandate; no obligation to reopen H&C assessment; daughter's s. 7 Charter rights not engaged as state action did not directly threaten her security
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) Removal Officer

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 44(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after visa expiration and following a removal order; cited daughter’s medical condition as reason for non-removal. No new evidence presented post-H&C review.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant (failed to leave after removal order)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of refusal to defer removal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of administrative immigration decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Prior H&C assessment, medical documentation, confirmation of healthcare access in home country
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of new or compelling evidence to justify deferral
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse credibility finding
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on child's medical needs
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 7 Charter analysis; discretion under IRPA s. 48
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably exercised discretion; no direct state deprivation of child's life, liberty, or security; adequate care available abroad
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) Removal Officer

Application_Facts: Ms. Hong provided evidence of her ties to Vietnam and financial support but failed to fully document her employment and financial capacity. The Visa Officer found her proposed studies unreasonable and insufficiently funded.
Procedural_Issue: Ms. Hong filed for judicial review after her visa denial.
Evidence_Used: Evidence of ties to Vietnam, financial support documents
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Incomplete documentation of employment and financial capacity
Credibility_Assessment: Proposed studies deemed unreasonable; intent to return questioned
Relief_Sought: Grant of student visa, overturning of refusal decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to demonstrate sufficient financial resources and intent to leave Canada after studies
Decision_Rationale: The Visa Officer reasonably concluded that Ms. Hong did not sufficiently demonstrate financial sufficiency or strong intent to return to Vietnam after her studies.

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment and lack of corroborating evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible due to failure to seek asylum in the US and inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Submitted documents deemed insufficient or unreliable
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to seek asylum during two-year stay in the US
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide credible evidence and explanation for delay
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to credibility assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Subjective fear undermined by delay and lack of action
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or supporting documents alleged

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment and procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish refugee status
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Delay in seeking asylum and inconsistent statements
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Credibility assessed under reasonableness; procedural fairness under correctness
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for credibility, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution in Turkey and conscientious objection to military service
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law standards in refugee determination
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimant failed to justify delays and inconsistencies
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of a question and allowance of judicial review

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility and timeliness of asylum application
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to delay and lack of corroborating evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral testimony and submitted documents given little weight
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Two-and-a-half-year stay in the US without seeking asylum
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to apply for asylum promptly in safe third country
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Documents submitted without sufficient independent verification
Crimes.Application_Factor: Subjective fear not supported by objective actions
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation through omission and delayed reporting
